Definitions.Definition_Content: A polynomial $f$ in a ring $R[X]$ is irreducible if it cannot be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials in $R[X]$.

An element $p$ in a unique factorization domain $R$ is called a prime element if it generates a prime ideal, i.e., the ideal $(p)$ is such that if $p$ divides a product of elements in $R$, then $p$ divides at least one of those elements.
The canonical homomorphism $\\[Phi: R[X] \\longrightarrow R /(p)[X]\\]$ is a ring homomorphism that reduces the coefficients of a polynomial modulo a prime element $p$ in $R$.

Theorems.Theorem_Content:
Let $R$ be a unique factorization domain and $f=a_{n} X^{n}+
...
+a_{0} \\in R[X]$ a primitive polynomial of degree $>0$. Assume there is a prime element $p \\in R$ such that $p \\nmid a_{n}$, $p \\mid a_{i}$ for $i<n$, and $p^{2} \\nmid a_{0}$. Then $f$ is irreducible in $R[X]$ and hence, by 2.7/7, also in $Q(R)[X]$.

Let $R$ be a unique factorization domain, $p \\in R$ a prime element, and $f \\in R[X]$ a polynomial of degree $>0$ whose leading coefficient is not divisible by p. If $\\[Phi(f)\\]$ is irreducible in $R /(p)[X]$, then the same is true for $f$ in $Q(R)[X]$. If in addition, $f$ is primitive, then it is irreducible in $R[X]$ as well.
